clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Study to Assess the Effectiveness of the Device Patello
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Study to Assess the Effectiveness of the Device Patello

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Applied Sciences and Arts of Southern Switzerland

clinical_study.source: University of Applied Sciences and Arts of Southern Switzerland

brief_summary.textblock: The device "Patello" was designed to passively mobilize the Patella in cranial-caudal direction. Its application field lays in the rehabilitation of any knee pathology where knee range of motion may be restricted due to the Patella mobility.

detailed_description.textblock: The effectiveness of the device Patello has not been tested so far. This clinical study aims to assess and proof the effectiveness of this device. The aim is to objectify the movement of the Patella induced by the device Patello in cranial / caudal direction. As outcome parameter serve ultrasound measurements of a bony reference point of the femur and the Patella and its displacement / distance after mobilization.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: One randomly selected knee is treated by the intervention device Patello

primary_outcome.description: The cranial-caudal mobilisation of the Patella is assessed during the mobilisation by means of the Patello.

intervention.description: The Patello is a new intervention device which mobilizes the Patella passively and continuously in cranial-caudal direction to increase Patella mobility.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- no operation and / or actual problems (pain at rest or during strain) of the muscular or bony parts of the lower extremities
- closed and intact skin conditions in the area of the knees and thighs
- no fear of the intervention
- willingness to participate on all 2 measurement days
Exclusion Criteria:
- operation and / or actual problems (pain at rest or during strain) of the muscular or bony parts of the lower extremities
- open skin conditions in the area of the knees and thighs
- fear of the intervention
- no willingness to participate on all 2 measurement days
